completeness.description: the extent to which the solution addresses all parts of the task.

correctness.description: the answers provided should be factually correct.

efficiency.description: the number of steps and amount of time taken by the agent system to reach the solution.

originality.description: the solution should not be directly copied from existing sources on the internet.

accuracy.description: the correctness of the final answer provided by the system.

response to correction.description: measure of how well the system can correct itself when given feedback

accepted_values.good: corrects errors with minor follow-up needed
accepted_values.poor: struggles to correct errors even with feedback

creativity.description: indicator of originality and creativity in problem-solving approach

accepted_values.not creative: approach is commonplace and lacks originality

resourcefulness.description: the ability to effectively utilize available resources (e.g., multi-agent systems) to obtain the answer.

accepted_values.optimal: resources are used in the most efficient and effective manner.
accepted_values.suboptimal: resources are used but not in the most efficient way.
accepted_values.ineffective: the use of resources did not contribute to obtaining the answer.

novelty.description: the originality of the answer, ensuring it has not been simply retrieved from readily available internet sources.

accepted_values.unique: the answer is uniquely produced and not found in plain text on the internet.
accepted_values.common: the answer is found with slight modifications from internet sources.
accepted_values.copied: the answer is an exact copy from internet sources.

collaboration.description: the effectiveness of the interaction among multiple agents to achieve the task.

adaptability.description: ability of the agents to handle unexpected situations or questions not explicitly covered by the available data

accepted_values.rigid: struggled with or ignored unexpected aspects

reliability.description: the consistency of the agent in providing correct solutions over multiple iterations or tasks.

understandability.description: how well a human can understand the solution and the steps that were taken by the agent(s) to reach it.

execution steps.description: the number of steps the agent needed to take to complete the task.

problem complexity.description: the level of difficulty of the question posed to the agent.

uniqueness of solution.description: the degree to which the provided solution is not readily found in existing data sources like the internet.

time efficiency.description: the amount of time it took for the agent to provide a solution.

data integrity.description: ensuring that the response does not contain any form of contamination from existing data sources.

resource identification.description: effectiveness in identifying and using the right resources to solve the task.

question understanding.description: the ability to understand the question’s complexity and requirements.

depth of analysis.description: how deeply the agents analyze information to reach a solution.

communication.description: the effectiveness with which the agent communicates the solution and reasoning path.

diversity and complexity coverage.description: the extent to which the solution covers diverse and complex aspects inherent in the task.

accepted_values.low: the solution covers only simple or a limited range of aspects.
accepted_values.medium: the solution covers a moderate range of diverse and complex aspects.
accepted_values.high: the solution thoroughly covers a wide range of diverse and complex aspects.

internet independence.description: the degree to which the solution can be derived without reliance on plain text answers from the internet.

accepted_values.dependent: the solution is derived from plain text found directly on the internet.
accepted_values.partially_independent: the solution references the internet but also demonstrates independent reasoning or computations.
accepted_values.independent: the solution is independent of internet search results and demonstrates original reasoning or computations.

relevance.description: the solution must directly address the posed question.

innovation.description: the level of creativity and originality in the problem-solving approach.

robustness.description: ability of the multi-agent system to handle diverse and unexpected inputs without errors.

linguistic competence.description: the ability to use and understand the language correctly in the context of the problem.

agent cooperation.description: the effectiveness of the agents working together to solve the task.

scalability.description: the ability of the solution to handle increasing amounts of work or scope

accepted_values.highly_scalable: solution can scale up to handle much larger tasks seamlessly
accepted_values.moderately_scalable: solution has some scalability but may struggle with significantly larger tasks
accepted_values.not_scalable: solution is not scalable, only suitable for small or specific tasks

informativeness.description: the degree to which the answer and reasoning provide valuable and relevant information

accepted_values.moderately informative: provides a fair amount of relevant information
accepted_values.minimally informative: provides some information, but not very detailed or relevant
accepted_values.not informative: provides no useful or relevant information

reasoning traceability.description: the ability to follow the logical reasoning and steps taken to arrive at the final answer.

accepted_values.partial: a partial reasoning trace is provided, but some steps or logic are unclear.
accepted_values.complete: a complete and clear reasoning trace is provided for all steps.

data contamination prevention.description: measures taken to ensure the solution does not rely on potentially contaminated or directly lifted data.
